name: Interjection
definition: An interjection is a word or phrase that expresses sudden emotion, surprise, or feeling, typically standing alone outside the main sentence. It's often followed by an exclamation mark or comma and adds emotional flavor to speech.
importance: Interjections give personality and emotion to our language. They express what we're feeling - surprise, joy, pain, agreement, or disgust - in a natural, authentic way. While not grammatically connected to the rest of the sentence, they make our communication more vivid and real.
tagline: Express emotion, surprise, and natural reactions!

types.name: Exclamations of Surprise
types.description: Express surprise, shock, or amazement at something unexpected.

types.name: Exclamations of Joy/Approval
types.description: Show happiness, excitement, pleasure, or approval.

types.name: Exclamations of Pain/Disgust
types.description: Express pain, discomfort, or negative reactions.

types.name: Exclamations of Agreement/Attention
types.description: Show agreement, understanding, or get someone's attention.

rules.title: DO: Use Exclamation Mark After Strong Interjections
points: Strong emotions = exclamation mark: 'Wow! That's amazing!'
Weak emotions = comma: 'Oh, I didn't realize that.'
An interjection can stand alone as its own sentence
examples: ‚úÖ Oh, I see what you mean.
‚úÖ Well, let me think about it.

rules.title: DO: Set Off Interjections with Punctuation
points: Interjections are separated from the main sentence
Use exclamation mark (!) for strong emotion
Use comma (,) for weak emotion or mild interjections
Interjections don't need to be part of the sentence structure
examples: ‚úÖ Hmm, I'm not sure about that.

rules.title: DO: Use Appropriate Interjections for Context
points: Choose interjections that match the situation and emotion
Informal conversations can use casual interjections
Formal writing uses fewer and milder interjections
Some interjections are region-specific (Blimey! is British)
examples: ‚úÖ Well, that's one way to solve it.

rules.title: DON'T: Overuse Interjections in Formal Writing
points: Formal essays shouldn't have many interjections
Save interjections for dialogue and informal communication
Too many interjections can make writing seem unprofessional
examples: ‚ùå Wow! This essay is so interesting! Gosh! I learned so much! Yay!
‚úÖ This essay presents interesting arguments that enhance our understanding.

rules.title: DON'T: Connect Interjections as Part of Sentence Structure
points: Interjections stand alone - they're not part of the sentence grammar
Don't connect them with 'and' or as subject/object
They're emotionally independent from the sentence
examples: ‚ùå 'Oh and I think that's wrong.' ‚Üí ‚úÖ 'Oh! I think that's wrong.'

examples.sentence: Wow! That's the most beautiful sunset I've ever seen!
Ouch! I burned my finger on the stove!
examples.usage_pattern: Interjection of pain expressing immediate reaction

examples.sentence: Congratulations! You passed your driving test!
Listen! Do you hear that strange noise?
examples.usage_pattern: Interjection of attention getting someone to focus

examples.sentence: Ugh, I can't stand this weather anymore.
examples.usage_pattern: Interjection of disgust with comma showing mild emotion

examples.sentence: Alas, our team didn't win the championship.
Absolutely! I completely agree with you!

exercises.title: Write Dialogue Using Interjections
exercises.prompt: Write a short conversation (8-12 lines) between two people. Include at least 8 different interjections. Use appropriate punctuation (! or ,) based on the emotion level. Make the dialogue natural and realistic.
exercises.sample_answer: 'Guess what?' 'What?' 'Wow! I got the job!' 'Congratulations! That's fantastic!' 'Thanks! I'm so excited!' 'You deserve it. By the way, are you going to the party?' 'Absolutely! I wouldn't miss it.' 'Great! See you there then.' 'Actually, ugh, I might be late.' 'Oh, no problem at all!'

exercises.title: Identify and Fix Interjection Errors
exercises.passage: Wow the sunset is beautiful! Oh I didn't see you there and are you okay? Ouch I think I hurt myself. Gosh and that was expensive! Great because we finally finished. Hmm well maybe we should try again. Yay I'm so happy and excited. Ugh it's so cold in here.
exercises.sample_answer: Wow! The sunset is beautiful! Oh, I didn't see you there. Are you okay? Ouch! I think I hurt myself. Gosh, that was expensive! Great! We finally finished. Hmm, maybe we should try again. Yay! I'm so happy and excited. Ugh! It's so cold in here.

common_mistakes.explanation: Interjections need exclamation mark or comma. 'Wow!' is a separate exclamation.

common_mistakes.error: Oh and I think you're right.
common_mistakes.explanation: Don't connect interjections with 'and'. They stand independently.

common_mistakes.error: Great, because we won the game.
common_mistakes.explanation: Use exclamation mark for strong emotion, not comma+because. Remove redundant 'because'.

common_mistakes.correct: Ugh! That's disgusting. (Or: Ugh, that's disgusting.)
common_mistakes.explanation: Interjections can't be the subject of a sentence. They must be set apart.

common_mistakes.correct: That doesn't hurt much. (Or: Ouch! That hurt!)
common_mistakes.explanation: Use exclamation mark for pain interjections, not comma, or use differently.
Don't use 'and' after interjections. Use appropriate punctuation.
Interjections stand alone. Don't use 'because' to connect to the main sentence.

common_mistakes.error: Well I think maybe we should go.
common_mistakes.correct: Well, I think maybe we should go.
common_mistakes.explanation: 'Well' as an interjection needs comma to separate from main sentence.

quick_facts: Interjections are one of the oldest parts of speech in English - they're very natural in conversation.
Interjections are very common in spoken English but less common in formal written English.
The word 'interjection' comes from Latin 'interjectus' meaning 'thrown between'.
Interjections don't have grammatical function in the sentence - they're emotionally functional.
Online, interjections are adapted: 'OMG!', 'LOL!', 'SMH' - showing digital communication style.
